Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Mining satellite data streams for commercial applications in natural resource monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth's human population has risen over seven-fold, from one to 7.3 billion people, in the last century and is expected to reach 9 billion by 2050. While droughts, floods, and other climatological extremes are increasing in frequency and severity, human population growth and increasing affluence are exerting unprecedented demands on Earth's ecosystems for food, water, and other resources. Threats of volatility have resulted in a growing demand for timely, accurate monitoring of renewable natural resources. Similar to the development of weather satellites in the past, terrestrial-observing satellites are now capable of providing consistent, long-term records of past, current, and projected future resources. There are two principal markets for this information. Managers of crop, range, forest, and wild lands require timely geospatial monitoring of land condition in order to plan stocking, treatment, and harvest levels. Meanwhile, financial entities must monitor these same ecosystems in order to predict yields, set commodity prices and insurance premiums, and to price instruments such as catastrophe bonds. To do this, data analysts in financial (e.g., investment, insurance) and natural-resource management sectors currently rely on indirect or coarsely scaled information such as regional tables for their analyses. This I-Corps team has developed a technology to provide high-resolution monitoring from satellite data streams that will enable more responsive land management and will increase liquidity and efficiency in resource and rural land markets. When paired with desktop and mobile visualization tools, these data have the potential to give resource managers real-time access to the "pulse of the planet" at local, regional, and global scales.

The three goals of this project are to: (1) validate the value proposition through customer discovery, (2) build a minimum viable product to demonstrate to potential partners and customers, and (3) conduct beta tests with early adopters. Based on these goals and the interviews to be conducted through the NSF I-Corps Teams program, this team will focus its efforts on specific resource (e.g., agriculture, forestry, urban development) and business (management, finance, insurance) sectors. The team will then refine its minimum viable product based on the results of these interviews and develop customer relationships. The team plans to have its first customer for geospatial data products. At the end of the I-Corps Teams program, this team will decide upon the commercial viability of products and services; and if deciding to move forward, the team will provide a transition plan to do so and a demonstration of the technology for potential partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth’s human population has risen over seven-fold, from one to 7.3 billion people, in the last century and is expected to reach 9 billion by 2050. While droughts, floods, and other climatological extremes are increasing in frequency and severity, human population growth and increasing affluence are exerting unprecedented demands on Earth’s ecosystems for food, water, and other resources. Threats of volatility have resulted in a growing demand for timely, accurate monitoring of renewable natural resources. Similar to the development of weather satellites in the past, terrestrial-observing satellites are now capable of providing consistent, long-term records of past, current, and projected future resources. There are two principal markets for this information. Managers of crop, range, forest, and wild lands require timely geospatial monitoring of land condition in order to plan stocking, treatment, and harvest levels. Meanwhile, financial entities must monitor these same ecosystems in order to predict yields, set commodity prices and insurance premiums, and to price instruments such as catastrophe bonds. To do this, data analysts in financial (e.g., investment, insurance) and natural-resource management sectors currently rely on indirect or coarsely scaled information such as regional tables for their analyses. We have developed a technology to provide high-resolution monitoring from satellite data streams that will enable more responsive land management and will increase liquidity and efficiency in resource and rural land markets. When paired with desktop and mobile visualization tools, these data have the potential to give resource managers real-time access to the “pulse of the planet” at local, regional, and global scales.

Agricultural and forest managers require real-time, geospatial monitoring in order to plan stocking, treatment, and harvest levels. Meanwhile, financial entities must monitor these same ecosystems in order to predict yields, set commodity prices and insurance premiums, and to price catastrophe bonds. Even rural property owners, buyers, and sellers need information on the condition, history, and potential of land. Whereas several national governments and a few private companies serve this growing demand with raw satellite imagery, only a few laboratories are capable of converting these data into information for agricultural or other resource management. 

The Global Land Cover Facility (GLCF; www.landcover.org), is a research lab at the University of Maryland and is the world’s largest open-access, non-governmental provider of satellite data products. Since its founding in 1998, GLCF has developed automated algorithms to produce satellite-based estimates of tree cover, urban impervious surface area, forest losses and gains, water inundation, and vegetation productivity. In 2015, GLCF submitted a provisional patent application for a process to “unmix” the signals of vegetation and other surface types in satellite imagery, enabling extraction of information at arbitrary spatial and temporal resolution. These data have the potential to give resource managers real-time access to the “pulse of the planet” at each of their individual scales of interest.

Through the I-Corps program, Entrepreneurial Lead Joseph Sexton conducted over 100 customer-discovery interviews to gauge demand for this product and to develop and refine a product-market fit. Sexton and his team of co-investigators also participated in a series of workshops to develop the business skills needed to get this technology out of academic and into the commercial world.

Their experience in the I-Corps program led to the conculsion that there is little current demand for their technology, simply because the user community is not poised to be able to adopt or use it. Therefore, they pivoted to become their own technology users and market derived products to a large, under-served community of geospatial information users: out-of state big-game hunters on public land in the Western US.
